name: Hotel Budir

reviews.title: a magical place
reviews.text: I would say that the Snaefellsnes peninsula is one of the most beautiful places in the world, and this hotel is the place to see it from. I was there in the early summer for my honeymoon, and for that I had a perfect time. It is important to realize that the area is quite remote and desolate, and this is very much the appeal. The hotel is the major landmark, and if you are going to a hotel in the area, I think besides one exception, this is it. Our room was clean, simple and elegant with a stunning view of the Snaefellsjokull glacier (this is room *23*) but if you have made trek to the peninsula, you will spend your best time outside. There are various hiking paths that will take you out through lava flows, past burned out volcanoes and to the amazing cliffs of Hellnar, eventually to the Snaefellsnes national park. The hotel takes its scenery seriously, and is laid out for you to enjoy the view, inside and out.

likes.disliked: — like any hotel in Iceland, it is quite expensive (especially after factoring in dinner) but otherwise as nice as any hotel in the country, but probably much more beautiful

reviews.text: The staff of course is friendly and very accommodating, and the restaurant serves haute cuisine. I have to say though, it is landscapes and the clouds spilling over the mountains that I remember foremost.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Hotel Budir is located in a nature preserve on the coastline of wild, gorgeous, dramatic western Iceland. Beautifully designed and well-maintained, with pretty public and private rooms, the hotel is a fantastic destination for nature lovers and comfort seekers alike. Some guest rooms have a glacier view, others overlook a majestic coastline studded by volcanic mountains, while still other rooms, such as the one we stayed in, have near views of a tidal estuary and long views of waterfalls and gorges across a lava field.

reviews.text: Iceland is a beautiful and fascinating country but it will never win any praise for its levels of service and its no surprise that the Budir ticks all these boxes. Its not that the service was outstandingly bad in any way, it just seemed that the bare minimum is kept to, which is fine in a 2 or 3-star property, but considering the hype around this hotel and the prices paid to stay and to eat, this hotel could certainly do a lot better, particularly the smaller touches.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The restaurant provided good food, certainly the local seafood banquet was huge and excellent quality, but did my wallet suffer or what ? I realise that Iceland isn't the cheapest place to visit and that Budir is marketed towards the higher spending visitors, but in excess of 300 Euros for a meal + wine for 2 people does seem a bit steep. Certainly there's nowhere else to go to nearby and the hotel makes the most of its captive market.
reviews.title: Overrated

reviews.title: Best location

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Stayed 2 nights. Lovely setting, great walks, nice building but food and service were awful. When we arrived there were teenagers sat outside the hotel in a cabin opposite playing very loud electric guitar, this continued for hours. We then endured the food which they couldn't even cook properly yet cost £100 for starter and main (we declined dessert), we ate at a petrol station the next night - this was more appealing. But by far the worst thing was the double standards, the hotel guests were told that they cannot not make any noise after 11pm, however it was OK for the hotel to hold a party until gone 2am! Something which kept the majority of guests awake half the night. I won't be wasting my money here again.
reviews.title: Nice Setting but they need to get their priorities straight.

reviews.title: Unbelievable scenery

description: Hotel Budir is undoubtedly one of the most beautiful countryside hotels in Iceland, just a short drive from Iceland’s capital city, Reykjavik. The hotel sits in a lava field on the westernmost tip of the Snaefellsnes peninsula, in the western region of Iceland.Due to the hotel’s location, guests have an impressive view of the breathtaking Snaefellsjokull glacier and the Budir-estuary which meanders into the vast Faxafloi-Bay where a number of seals reside.Over the winter time its cozy sitting by the fireplace having hot chocolate and enjoying the amazing northern lights Aurora borealis just outside the hotel.Hotel Budir’s restaurant, arguably one of the most romantic restaurants in Iceland, has been referred to as "The Mecca of Icelandic cooking", due to its unique and delightful cuisine. The restaurant’s menu is seasonal and takes advantage of fresh local produce like seafood and fish from neighbouring villages such as Stykkisholmur, Olafsvik and Borgarnes.The hotel also organises and hosts a number of weddings, all of which are unique and tailor made with the wedding couple or their representatives. Many of the weddings ceremonies are conducted in the little church close to Hotel Budir or in the hotel reception; it is even possible to get married on the golden sand beach close to the hotel.In addition, the hotel also offers facilities for meetings and small-to-medium sized conferences thus making it ideal for business-meetings or conferences with colleagues.Hotel Budir has it all, a world-class service, fine food and drink and luxurious rooms, making it ideal for get-togethers with friends and family, or a romantic weekend with a loved one – all of which can be enjoyed in an indescribably beautiful environment.
